for stealing, on the 7th of July, 1 pair of shoes, value 9s., the goods of
John Cearney; 1 knife, value 5d., and 1 bag, value 1d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Osborn.
JOHN CEARNEY . I live at No. 29, New-street, Deptford. On the 7th of July I bought a pair of shoes of O'Brien—I lost them—these are very much like them—I had them only an hour in my possession.

ELIZABETH OSBORN . I live at No. 29, New-street, in the same house with Cearney. I know the prisoner—he came to my house on the 7th of July to sup—I do not know where the shoes were then—I believe he had the knife at his supper—I have got one or two of the same sort—I missed a knife and bag—I suppose that is it—I have got more knives like it, and there were more persons in the house at the time.
NOT GUILTY .

1998.
JOHN MUMFORD was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
Daniel Dench, from his person.

JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) Last Wednesday I was on duty in plain clothes on the race-course at Lee, and saw the prisoner go behind the prosecutor and take this handkerchief—I took him with it in his hand.
JOHN DENCH . This is my brother Daniel's handkerchief—it was in his pocket—I was with him at the time.
Prisoner. I had just come out of a booth that minute to look at the races, and he took me—I never had the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined One Year; One Month Solitary.

1999.
THOMAS MOODY was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Lee Wright, from his person.

JOSEPH LEE WRIGHT . I am a surgeon, and live at Rotherhithe. On the 17th of August I was at Eltham races—I felt a tug, and turned and saw my handkerchief in the prisoner's hand—he scuffled and ran—this is my handkerchief.
Prisoner. I was standing at the table—there was a handkerchief thrown towards me, and he knocked me down.
WILLIAM PULLEY . I am a police-officer. I was there, and saw the pri soner when he was taken—he said he was done, or done for, alluding to himself, I suppose—I believe he said he was done for.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year; One Month Solitary.

2000.
JOHN CROUCHER was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 1 hat, value 5s.; the goods of
John Goodenough.

JOHN GOODENOUGH . I am a watchman. I was at Eltham races—I put my hat under the seat, and fell asleep between ten and eleven o'clock at night, on the 17th of August—somebody gave me information, and I went and found my hat on the prisoner's head about an hour after I had lost it—this is it.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months; Six Weeks Solitary.

2001.
MARY CANE was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of August 1 tureen, value 1s.; 1 dish, value 1s.; 3 table-napkins, value 1s. 6d.; 1 handkerchief value 6d.; 1 knife, value 6d.; 1 cream jug, value 6d.; the goods of
George Collier, her master; and 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; and 1 pair of scissors, value 6d.; the goods of
Louisa Collier; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Prosecutrix.
Confined Three Months.

2002.
ANN MURRELL was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of June, 1 ring, value 20l.; 1 other ring, value 1l.; 1 brooch, value 5l.; 3 pairs of stockings, value 15s.; 10 yards of lace, value 2l.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 5s.; 2 table cloths, value 1l.; 6 knives, value 8s.; 6 forks, value 7s.; 1 bed-gown, value 1s.; and 1£20 bank-note; the goods and property of
William Canty, her master, in his dwelling-house: and
JOHN SCANNELL
for feloniously receiving the brooch and note, being part of the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen.—2nd COUNT, for receiving them of an evil disposed person—Scannell pleaded

GUILTY to second Count.—
Judgment respited.

(
No evidence was offered against Murrell, who was acquitted.)

2003.
RICHARD DAVIS and
WILLIAM SMITH were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Hunter, on the 4th of August, at St. Mary, Lambeth, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 watch, value 1l. 10s.; 2 spoons, value 5s.; 1 locket, value 5s.; 2 brooches, value 5s.; and 1 twopenny-piece; his goods and monies.

MARY HUNTER . I am the wife of John Hunter, and live at Herne-lodge, Herne-hill, Surrey. On the 4th of August I left the lodge between four and five o'clock to go up to the house, leaving the door and window secure—I returned in about half an hour, and saw the prisoner Smith going out of the lodge gate, and Davis getting out of the window which I had fastened—when they saw me they both ran away, one on the Norwood-road, and the other towards Camberwell—I called out, "Police, stop thief"—I saw Davis stopped—I never lost sight of him—he was given into the charge of a policeman—I went back to the lodge, and found the middle pane of the window broken, the catch unfastened, and the bottom sash thrown up—I missed awatch from a case on the mantel-shelf, and two spoons, two brooches, a locket, and a twopenny-piece, from a drawer—I afterwards saw them at the station-house—these are them—(looking at them)—they are my husband property.

JAMES BRISSENDEN . I am a policeman. On the 4th of August, about five o'clock, I took charge of Davis, on Herne-hill, about 200 yards from the lodge—the other prisoner was in custody at the same time—I searched them both, and found two brooches and a locket in Smith's pocket, which I have brought here—Mrs. Hunter brought the watch to the station-house—I found a piece of brass on Davis—I went back, and found the two spoons within about two yards of where Smith was stopped.
MRS. HUNTER re-examined. The watch was thrown away at the time they were stopped, and given to me by a person who is present, in less than two minutes after I saw Davis come out of the window.

THOMAS PICKETT . I am coachman to Mrs. Lock, of Herne-hill. Be tween four and five o'clock on the 4th of August, I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I saw two men running out of the lodge gate, and the prosecutrix after them—I went up and met Smith—I took him by the collar, and handed him over to the policeman—Davis ran the other way, and I did not see him taken—when Smith was passing the shrubbery I saw his arm go, but could not tell what he had thrown away—after the prosecutrix stated what she had lost, I took the policeman back with me, and found these two silver spoons in the direction I had seen his arm go.

SAMUEL LUFF . I am a glazier. I was at work near the lodge on the 4th of August, between four and five o'clock, and heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I turned round, and saw a watch fall into the carriage-drive in front of the house—I picked it up and gave it to Mrs. Hunter—I ran out into the road as soon as I picked it up, and saw Davis in custody of a stranger.
Davis's Defence. I was coming from Dulwich. I saw a person running, I ran too, and was stopped—two or three more lads were running at the same time, but they did not offer to stop them.

Smith's Defence. I was coming from Norwood. I saw a person run fling something from his hand—I ran and picked these things up, and directly afterwards a person ran hallooing out "Stop thief" towards Camberwell, from Norwood.

DAVIS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

2004.
WILLIAM SHADE was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of June, 1 time-piece, value 8l.; and 1 glass shade, value 3s.; the goods of
Elizabeth Metcalf, in her dwelling-house.

JANE ROBARTS . I am nineteen years old. I was servant to Mrs. Metcalf at Newington. On Friday morning, the 30th of June, about twelve o'clock, I went out for some porter—my mistress and her sister were in the house at the time—as I went out, I saw the prisoner on the grass plot in front of the house, with some ornamental shavings for stoves, in a blue handkerchief—he was about two yards from the front parlour window—there was a beautiful time-piece on the mantel-piece there—I saw the prisoner again a day or two afterwards in custody, and am confident he is the man—I was taken up to be a witness myself—I dare say I was gone a quarter of an hour for the beer—the window was wide open when I went, and when I came back I saw my mistress reaching out of the window, to get the shavings which were on the ground, close under the window—they were in the same blue handkerchief I had seen the man with.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where did you go for the beer? A. To the top of West-street, about a quarter of a mile from the house—there was a public-house nearer than that—I have lived with my mistress about six months—a gentleman comes twice a week to see my mistress—he does not always sleep there—he goes next morning about ten o'clock—I have come from prison now—I was sent there to give evidence—I was discharged from my situation, and I was sent to the poor-house first—I did not say any thing to the man when I saw him in the front garden, nor to my mistress—I have always said it was twelve o'clock that I went out—I am quite sure of that—I did not say it was eleven o'clock—what I said before the Magistrate was read over to me, and I made my mark to it.
(The witness's deposition being read, stated it was eleven o'clock when she went out for the beer, and that she left the window a little way open.)

Q. Now, having heard that read, was it not about eleven o'clock? A. Yes, I think it was—I am sure the window was wide open when I went my—I did not say before the Magistrate that it was a little way open—I think it was a little way open—I did not say any thing before the Magistrate about my mistress reaching out of the window when I came back—I had been in service twelve months before I lived with my mistress—she did not lose the time-piece before, while I was with her.

COURT. Q. How long have you been in this prison? A. Two days—this is the second day—after I went before the Magistrate, I said I would not give evidence against the man—my mistress told that to the overseer, and then they sent me to prison to give evidence—I am very sorry for it now.

ELIZABETH METCALF . The last witness was my servant. I sent her for some beer about eleven o'clock in the morning of the 30th of June—she was away about a quarter of an hour—I went into the front parlour be fore she went for the beer, to see the time, and the time-piece was then on the mantel-piece—the window was a little way open then—I went into the parlour again just as she was coming back, and the window was wide open, and the time-piece gone—under the window, outside, I found a bundle of shavings in a blue handkerchief—I had no shavings in my par lour—there were the marks of a man's shoe under the window—my servant was very insolent after going to Union Hall—she would not do her

work, and said if I discharged her I should have the 40l. to pay, as I was bound over to appear, and that was the cause of her going away—she went to the poor-house at first—she was not charged with being concerned in this.

Cross-examined. Q. What time did you look at the clock? A. About eleven o'clock—I once before had the time-piece taken out of the window, but got it back again—the room had been swept, and the window was open—the man who took the clock the first time was caught by a person who took it from him, and he got off—there was only me and my sister in the house, besides my servant—no gentleman—I shall not answer any him pertinent questions.
NOT GUILTY .

2005.
HENRY RUSSELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of August, 1 purse, value 3d.; 1 sovereign, and 3s.; the goods and monies of
Josiah Attwell.

JOSIAH ATTWELL . I am in the employ of Joseph Reeve—I was engaged on board the ship Excel, which laid at Carpenter Smith's wharf. On Thursday, the 3rd of August, master gave me a sovereign to pay some ballast-men—I put it into a purse, with 3s. in silver, and put it into my waistcoat pocket—immediately after I went down to have my tea—I took the purse out of my pocket, put it on the cabin table, and left it there—I came on deck after tea, and sent the prisoner down to have his tea—he is steward of the vessel—I afterwards missed my purse, and said to him, "Steward, I have lost my purse with a sovereign and 3s. in it"—he said, "It is a bad job"—I afterwards saw the policeman take it from him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure you left it on the table? A. At first I was not—nor before the Magistrate, but I have studied about it since, and am now certain of it—I told the Magistrate I thought so, but I am positive now—I searched for it in the cabin, and every where I could think of, and down the hold, as I was not sure then that I had left it on the table—I did not say I thought it might have fallen overboard when I was hauling up the fender—I was not asked that question before the Magistrate—I searched among the ballast—I was down there about a minute, and said to the prisoner, "It is no use looking here, I think I left it on the cabin-table—I saw it again on Saturday, the 5th—the prisoner, had been steward about three months—I believe he comes from Deal—his father is a Deal pilot—I had a quarrel with the prisoner ten days before this—I told him to do his duty—to mop the deck, and he said, "I shan't"—he was cooking the dinner—I did not strike him—he threatened to strike me with the tormentors, and I took them from him—I did not say I would fight him for it—nor any thing of the sort—I never said that I struck him—he was aggravating me, and I said, "Now take and drop it, there's a good fellow—you want to vex me to strike you, and get me into trouble," and that was all that passed—I can swear to this purse—(looking at it)—I bought it at Cardiff—there is one very small black spot at one end, where I put the money in, and I know it by the ring—I had had it about six weeks.

CHARLES LAKE . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody in Vine-yard, Tooley-street—I asked him if he had any money—he said he had—I asked if he had a purse, and he drew this purse from his pocket with four sovereigns in it—I handed it to Attwell, and he said it was his purse.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he give it up to you directly? A. Yes—he was about 200 yards from the wharf.
MICHAEL BARRY . I know the prosecutor—I have seen him with a green purse very much like this—I saw him put some money into it.
NOT GUILTY .

2006.
WILLIAM SERJEANT,
THOMAS WILLIAM HILL,
ROBERT JOHNSON , and
THOMAS NICHOLLS , were indicted for
killing and slaying
Elizabeth Ford.

GEORGE SKILLECORN . I am a butcher, and live in Blackfriars-road. On the 8th of July, about ten o'clock in the evening, I observed two cabs coming abreast down Blackfriars-road, towards the Elephant and Castle—they were coming, according to my judgment, at from twelve to fourteen miles an hour—the horses were at full gallop—the drivers were flogging their horses—the one that drove the grey horse hit it twice as they passed my door—I observed a female crossing the road, and saw the cab with the grey horse knock the woman down—I imagine it was done with the shaft—it appeared to me so—the woman lay between the horse and the cab, and the cab passed over her—several people called out to the man to stop, as he had knocked a woman down, but he immediately flogged his horse and went on as fast as he could, and never stopped at all—the woman was picked up and taken next door to me, and then to another surgeon—I do not know who was the driver of the cab—it was a grey horse—the other horse appeared a sort of chesnut, and was on the other side of the road.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you at your own house? A. Yes—it was light, because I have two gas burners outside, and my neighbour has a light also—the cabs were together till they came opposite my door, and there being a coach-rank there, one took one side of the road, and the other the other—they were in the middle of the road till they came within a few yards of the corner of Cross-street—they were on a level before that—there were persons in both cabs—there were two in the nearest to me, besides the driver—I cannot speak to the other.

COURT. Q. Could you form any judgment, from the manner of driving, whether they were racing? A. I should say it was evident they were, or they would not be galloping so, and both trying to pass each other—they seemed to try which could get to the end of the coach rank first—it was evident to me they were racing—both galloped as fast as they could.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you always say there was somebody in the grey horse cab? A. I do not know whether there was one or two—I always knew there was somebody in it—I have not always said so, for at the moment I could not see the parties in the cab—my attention was more taken up with my customers at that time—I did not hear any expression from any body.

AUGUSTUS MULLINGS . I am a bell-hanger, and live in Aldermanbury. I was in Blackfriars-road on this night, on the Christ-church side of the way—the same side as Skillecorn—I saw two cabs coming down the road at a very great rate—going at full speed, galloping as fast as they could go—the one with a grey horse was striving to gain on the other, which was on the opposite side of the way when I saw it—I saw a female in the act of crossing the road—she had no sooner entered the road than the grey horse knocked her down; and as soon as the woman was knocked down, the driver hit the horse with all his force two or three times, and by the time the horse got to the spot where I was, I darted into the middle of the

road and told the driver to stop—he did not, and I caught hold of the rail of the cab behind, and followed it all the way down the road, till it came to Wellington-street—I hallooed out to him to stop—he told me to leave go—I said, "No, unless you stop I will never leave you"—he then turned into Wellington-street, and as he turned round he lashed me with the whip—when we gained the other corner of the street I left his rail, and darted across to gain the reins of the horse if I could, but I caught hold of the end of the shaft—there were two men in the cab, and one of them, who I can swear was Johnson, was leaning on the knee board, and he said to the driver, with very blasphemous words, "D—his eyes, the b——, on to him, lay it into him, make him leave go"—Serjeant was the driver—after Johnson said this, Serjeant got up, and with his whip lashed me so hard that I was obliged to leave go of the shaft—he lashed me over the back and hands—I had held on for the distance of about an hundred and eighty yards, and was then obliged to leave go of the shaft—I then hung on the rail behind, and hallooed out "Stop this cab "till we got about fifty yards farther, when a policeman jumped off the pavement, and told him to stop, and said, "If you do not I will pull you off your seat"—by that time the horse began to slacken his pace, and up came another witness, who had been in pursuit all the way, and I gave Serjeant into custody.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you observe whether the men in the cab were intoxicated? A. I should say they were rather in toxicated—they had been drinking.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did the grey horse appear going at speed at first? A. It did, running as fast as the driver could make him go—I saw the cabs for a distance of two hundred yards before it went over the woman—I was within twenty yards of the woman when she was knocked down.
JURY. Q. Was the driver of the cab drunk? A. He was perfectly sober—I never saw him before—he was taken on the spot.

COURT. Q. Could you form a judgment whether the cabs were both or either of them running away, or racing? A. The grey horse one was trying to gain on the other, and when it knocked the woman down it had gained ten yards on it—they were both driven by the drivers, urged on, I am certain—I believe Nicholls was in the cab, but I will not swear to him.

CHARLES BOORE . I am a bricklayer, and live in Arlington-street, Waterloo-road. On the 8th of June I was in Blackfriars-road, and ob served the cabs—I was right opposite where the woman was killed, and on the same side of the way as Mulling's—they were galloping at full rate, the between fourteen and fifteen miles an hour—the drivers were flogging their horses before the woman was run over—I was standing there, taking notice, and saw the woman on the curb-stone—I said to her, "For God's sake, get out of the way, and she was immediately knocked down—the two fore-feet of the horse went, one on one side of her head, and the other the other—I followed till the cab was stopped—a gentleman was going to take the number of the cab—I said, "That won't do; the woman is dead;" and the prisoners were taken into custody—when we called to them to stop he kept flogging his horse faster and faster—they both flogged their horses, and the brown horse was on the wrong side of the road—there were two persons in each cab besides the driver.

CHARLES BERNEY . I am a solicitor, and lived in Bell's-buildings, Salisbury-square, at the time. I was in Blackfriars-road on the night in question, and observed the cabs—they were racing—both drivers whipping

their horses, and galloping along as hard as they could—I saw the grey horse knock a woman down, and after that both cabs increased their speed, if possible—both drivers whipped their horses after that—I heard them called to to stop—I saw the woman taken to Mr. Vardy's, a surgeon—I went to the station-house, at the request of a policeman, and there saw Serjeant, the driver of the cab—he admitted to me that he was the driver—he sat there, with his whip in his hand—I saw Nicholls there—he was very impertinent to me, and said they were not racing; and what I had said was all false; that he was in the cab, and they were not racing, but the horse had run away.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where the woman was run over, I believe there was a line of carriages in the middle of the road? A. They had not reached the line of carriages—I will swear that—they were nearly the length of this court short of them—the cabs were more in the centre of the road at first, but as they approached towards the stand they both verged to the right—they did not divide, in my opinion; but in consequence of the woman being knocked down, I lost sight of the cabs—as my attention was taken about the woman I did not see them at the stand—she was ten or twelve feet from the pavement.

JOHN GRAVE STOCK (police-constable N 163.) I was on duty near Suffolk street, and saw a cab with a grey horse turn from Wellington-street into Suffolk-street, at a very rapid rate, and heard a cry of "Stop the cab with the grey horse"—I went in pursuit, and found it stopped by a brother constable—we took the cab and the parties to the station-house—I saw Johnson in the cab, besides Serjeant—I went to the woman, in the doctor's shop—she was still alive—I assisted in taking her to the hospital, and she died before we got there.
TOBIAS CHAPMAN (police-constable N 129.) I stopped the cab with the grey horse, and took Serjeant to the station—I saw two men in the cab besides—Johnson was one of them.

DAVID CORSTORPHAN . I am a police-inspector. I was on duty that night—about twenty minutes after ten o'clock Serjeant was brought to the station-house, and Johnson and Nicholls followed—Serjeant gave his name—the constable stated in his hearing that the woman had been run over by his cab—I asked him what he had got to say to it—he said it was true—Johnson immediately said he was in the cab along with him, and he did all he could to stop the horse; and Nicholls said afterwards that the horse got the better of Serjeant.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were not Johnson and Nicholls decidedly tipsy? A. They were.
HENRY ASSITER . I took the woman to Mr. Vardy's—I saw her after wards at the hospital, and saw the same body at the inquest.

JONATHAN BEER . I am a cab driver. I know Hill perfectly well, and have seen Serjeant on the rank—Johnson has been ostler to Serjeant of late, and the other is what they call a lawyer, or something—I never saw him with Serjeant—on Saturday night, the 8th of July, I was on the stand in Farringdon-street—the prisoners were also on the stand—I heard Hill challenge to race Serjeant from Farringdon-street to the Surrey-gate—they agreed—and each drew up to the curb and took two passengers—the other two prisoners got into Serjeant's, and two others in their company got into Hill's—I saw them leave—Hill returned again, I think, about half-past ten o'clock the same evening, and said to the by-standers, "They have run over a b——old woman, and I turned down a street, by which
means I got out of the way"—Knight, a waterman, was present at the time—I did not go to the police-office till a few days after.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you go before the Coroner? A. No—I heard of the inquest, but I had to look for my living—I am not doing any thing now—I was working for Gregory at the time—I believe he had a disagreement with Hill—I gave evidence before I went into Gregory's employ—I did not go before the Magistrate of my own accord—I had a conversation with Gregory the night before about this.
ELIZABETH MILLS . I am the mother of the deceased Elizabeth Ford, she was a widow—she was in very good health before this—she has left an orphan five years old—my daughter was not deaf.

JAMES ARMSTRONG NUTT . I am a surgeon of Bartholomew Hospital. The body of the woman was brought in quite dead—I found a fracture of the base of the skull and the lower jaw—I believe she died from fracture and concussion of the brain—the accident described would account for her death.
(The prisoners, Serjeant and Nicholls, received good characters.)

SERJEANT—
GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined One Year.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

NICHOLLS—
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Confined One Month.

HILL—
NOT GUILTY .

2007.
JULIA MAHONEY was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
David Stanley, at St. Mary, Rotherhithe, about the hour of one, in the night of the 13th of August, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 shawl, value 1s.; 1 handkerchief, value 4d.; 2 caps, value 6d.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 3d.; 1 salt-cellar, value 2d.; 2 prints, framed and glazed, value 6s.; his goods: and 1 waistcoat, value 4s.; and 1 pair of trowsers, value 6s.; the goods of
Jonathan Stanley.

JONATHAN STANLEY . I am the the son of David Stanley, who lives in the parish of Rotherhithe. On Sunday night, the 13th of August, I came home from work, at two o'clock in the morning, or before two—I found the street door was wide open, and the lower-sash of the window was up—I went in at the door, and I called out, but no answer was given—I called out again, but my father was asleep—I called again, and at last he made an answer, and said he would bring me a light—I then heard a female voice say, "Let me out"—my father came down stairs with a light, (I had shut the door before he came down,) and I saw the prisoner with a shawl on, two caps and a handkerchief—she had her shoes in her hand—I left her with my father, and went for a policeman—I returned in five minutes—she still had the shawl on, and the handkerchief, two caps, and a pair of child's trowsers in her possession—my sleeve-waistcoat, and a pair of trowsers were on the floor—they had been brought down two pair of stairs—and two pictures and a salt-cellar were on a table in the room—I knew the prisoner before, but she never lived in the house—the policeman took her.

CHARLES HOWE . I am a policeman. The prosecutor brought me to the house on Monday morning, about two o'clock—I took the prisoner into custody, and took part of these things from her, and the rest were in the room—as I took her to the station-house I saw a cotton handkerchief fall from her.
ELIZABETH STANLEY . I am the wife of David Stanley, of Rotherhithe.

We went to bed last Sunday night at ten minutes after nine o'clock—I saw my husband lock the door—the window was shut, and the shutters put too, but not bolted—it was left so on purpose for my son to get in—the articles produced are ours, except my son's waistcoat and trowsers—they were in the house that night—my shawl hung on a bonnet, on a peg, and the prisoner had the shawl on her shoulders—I took it off her, and the cap out of her bosom, when I came down with my husband.
Prisoner's Defence. A man came up to me, and asked where I was going—I was very much in liquor—he said he would take me home—he took me there, and this young man came in. Witness. She was sober.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Death recorded.

2008.
JOSEPH JACKSON and
GEORGE ROBINSON were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Fulford, on the 3rd of August, at St. Mary Magdalen, Bermondsey, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 gown, value 5s.; 1 shawl, value 10s.; 1 printed book, value 1s. 6d.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; 1 bed-gown, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shift, value 2s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 7 aprons, value 3s.; 1 petticoat, value 2s.; 1 brush, value 1s.; and 2 caps, value 1s.; the goods of
Hannah Fulford.

HANNAH FULFORD . I am the sister of William Fulford, and live with him, in Long-lane, Bermondsey. On the 3rd of August, about five o'clock in the morning, the policeman alarmed my brother—I went down stairs, and found a square of glass taken out of the back parlour window, which had been fastened, but was then wide open—I found the front door open, which I had bolted, top and bottom, the night before—there is a garden behind the house—I had placed a bundle of wearing apparel on the side board, under the back window, which I found open, and they were gone then—these are my things (looking at them.)

THOMAS BEST . On Thursday morning, the 3rd of August, about five o'clock, I was going to work, and saw a man standing at the prosecutor's door; and, in about a minute, I saw two men come out, both with bundles, and go up the lane, towards St. George's church—I could not alarm the people of the house, but I kept my eye on them a good way—I saw a policeman, and told him—I lost sight of them before I saw the policeman, but had a good view of them, and I am certain it was the prisoners—I had seen them before.
Jackson. He watched me down Long-lane—this door was wide open, and the bundle lying at it—there was nobody with me. Witness. There were two more with him.
Robinson. I was going to work—I know nothing of it. Witness. I am quite sure he was standing at the door—the others had the bundles.

THOMAS CORSTON . I am a policeman. Best gave me information about a quarter past five o'clock—I went towards St. George's church, and, after getting round a nook about fifty yards from the prosecutor's house, I saw the two prisoners in company together, walking on the pavement—Jackson had a bundle—I followed them to Richardson-street—they saw me, and turned up again—I followed, and saw them together in King-street, and took them in the Borough—I asked Jackson what he had in the bundle—he made no answer, but looked confused—I desired another man to take Robinson, and he ran away up Union-street; but I saw him appre
hended
—they were both before the Magistrate about half past eleven o'clock that day.

Robinson. I was not in company with the man at all—I was across the road. Witness. I saw them together three times between the house and the Borough—they walked about a mile together. Jackson. The witness would say any thing for a day's pay.

JACKSON—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

ROBINSON—
GUILTY . Aged 29.

2009.
MARY LYONS and
JOHN SCANNELL were indicted for
feloniously uttering to
George William Dean a forged £10 bank-note, with intent to defraud
John Jupp, well knowing it to be forged: and
CATHERINE MURPHY
as an accessary after the fact.

GEORGE WILLIAM DEAN . I am foreman to John Jupp, a silversmith and salesman, High-street, Borough. On Saturday, the 24th of June, the prisoner Lyons came into the shop, with a little boy and Scannell—they purchased a suit of clothes for the boy, which came to 19s.—Lyons gave me what appeared a £10 Bank of England note—Scannell had very little to do with purchasing the clothes—he said he hoped it was a nice suit, as it was for a motherless child—on looking at the note I saw it was a very old date, and a bad-looking one—I said to Lyons, "How is it this note, bearing the date of 1832, has not been paid into the Bank of England?" and asked her something regarding her possession of it—I could not exactly say what it was, but I was satisfied with her answer, though I forget what the answer was—she did not ask me any questions—she gave the address Mary Lyons, and said she lived at No. 7, Cornwall-road, Blackfriar's-road—I wrote that on the face of the note—I have since been there, and found no such person living there; and I inquired at No. 7, Cornwall-place, and no such person had ever lived there—the note has been since sent to the Bank of England.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. You are not certain whether the male prisoner said the child was his? A. I am not—he took very little part in the purchase—they came in together—Lyon's did not ask me if the note was a good one—I am quite sure if she had asked such a question, I should not have taken it—I cannot charge my memory with the conversation which took place—I am quite certain she did not say she lived at No. 7, Broadwall, Blackfriars-road—I know Broadwall—it is very near Cornwall-road—I have not inquired at Broadwall—the prisoner said, before the Magistrate, that I had made a mistake in putting down her ad dress—the note was dirty and rumpled.

HENRY RICHARD BRETT . I am shopman to Mr. Bayfield, pawnbroker, in Charlotte-terrace, New-cut. I have a suit of boy's clothes which were pawned at our shop, in the name of "Mary Buckley," by the prisoner Murphy, on the 29th of June.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen her before? A. Not to my knowledge—I saw her again at Union Hall, some time after—I can positively swear to her—I recollect her person so well—she was in the shop for ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, as there was somebody in the shop at the time—I never expressed a doubt of her identity—I did not say at Union Hall, that I thought she was the person—I never felt a doubt from first to last.

THOMAS REDFORD (police-constable L 52.) I took Lyons and Murphy into custody, in a court, off Broadwall, in a house—I went into the room, and found them there—there was a little girl at the window—I found an image on the mantel-piece with several duplicates in it—I asked Murphy who they belonged to—she said to her—among them was one for a suit of clothes pawned at Bayfield's—when I took them out, Murphy said, "You have found something."
Cross-examined. Q. Were they lying openly in the image? A. No—poked up inside it—the other prisoner had been taken before.
JOSHUA FREEMAN . I am Inspector of Bank Notes to the Bank. This note is a forgery in every respect, paper, plate, and signature.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it so bad that it could not deceive a person of ordinary caution? A. It is bad, but an illiterate person might take it—I think, with due caution, it would not be taken—it is a very indifferent one.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Justice Williams.

div1.p:
2010.
JOHN CRONIN was indicted
for a rape.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Death recorded.

2011.
JOHN FAITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of May, at St. George the Martyr, Southwark, 1 pocket-book, value 5s.; 1£300 1£100, 1£40, 1£30, and 1£5, bank-note; 1 Bill of Exchange for£5 11s. 2d. 1 for£25 7s. 6d., 1 for£292 2s. 9d., 1 for£9 9s. 8d., 2 for£100, 2 for£500, 1 for£24 5s., 1 for£58 14s. 7d., 1 for 6s. 8d., 1 for£1 12s., and 1 for£95 11s. 9d., the goods and property of
Abraham Wildey Robarts, and others; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Year.

2012.
EDMUND POWNALL was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Sherlock, on the 13th of August, at St. Mary, Lambeth, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 22 yards of linen-cloth, value 6l.; 1 watch, value 3l.; and 1 pair of ear-rings value 9s.; his goods: and
THOMAS WHITE
for feloniously receiving 7 yards of linen cloth, value 3s.; and 1 pair of ear-rings, value 9s.; part of the said goods, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

HENRY SHERLOCK . I live in Pownall-terrace, Kennington, in the parish of St. Mary, Lambeth—I am the housekeeper. On Sunday morning, the 13th of August, I went out, leaving nobody in the house—I re turned about half-past eight o'clock—it was dark—I went into the back parlour—my wife tried the drawer in that room, and found the lock had been forced—the key of the cupboard was kept in that drawer—next morning we missed some linen from the first floor front room—from a box which was open, and a watch from a trunk in my bed-room—the trunk was locked—I found an opening made in the tiles of the roof of the house—I afterwards found the prisoners in custody at Tower-street station house, and Pownall said he had got into the house by the roof, by displacing the tiles, that he got into the loft, and then into the front attic, and that he took a pair of ear-rings from the drawer—on returning home, I missed the ear-rings—I have since seen my watch, which is worth 3l., and ear rings, worth 8s. or 9s., and a piece of Irish linen, worth 6l.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did he not say he found the street door open, and went in, and took the things while the family were at breakfast? A. No—he told me himself, at the police-office, that he got in at the roof, and I mentioned it to the Magistrate, and the clerk took it down—I thought it was read over to me, but it is not in my deposition, and must have escaped my notice (the deposition being read, omitted to state this fact)—my house is next door to the prisoner's—the linen is now in two pieces—I had not cut it—there are twenty-three yards of it—it is worth 5s. 6d. a yard at the wholesale price—it is very fine.
HENRY BESSANT . I live with Mr. Wasson, of Mount-street, Lambeth. I produce a pair of ear-rings, which were pawned by the prisoner White, on Monday morning, the 14th of August, about eleven o'clock.

DAVID PEARSON . I am a policeman. In consequence of information, I went, betweeen nine and ten o'clock on Monday night, the 14th, to the house where White lives with his father, in Chesterton-street, Kennington, and saw him—I asked him if he knew any thing about the robbery over the road—he at first said no—I asked if he had pawned any thing—he said, "Yes, a piece of linen"—I said, "Where did you get it?"—he said, "From young Pownall, and pawned it for 10s. at Mr. Philmer's"—I said, "Is that all you have pawned to-day?"—he said, "No, I pawned a pair of ear-rings"—I said, "Is that all?"—he said, "Yes, that is all I pawned, but Pownall has pawned a watch at the same place that I pawned the ear-rings"—I went and took Pownall, and he denied all knowledge of it—I fetched White to him, and directly he saw him he acknowledged that he had stolen the property, and pawned it; he said that he got in through the tiles, and he gave it to White to pledge—he said at first that he walked through the passage, and went up at the time the prosecutor was at break fast; but afterwards he said he got out of his father's house, which is next door, into the prosecutor's through the tiles, and that he cut seven yards of linen off in his father's room, and sent it to be pawned for 10s. by White—at the station-house he said there was a piece of linen concealed in his father's loft—I went and searched the loft, and found this linen con cealed behind a large piece of mahogany.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure he said he got in through the tiles? A. Yes—I told the Magistrate so—I do not know whether it was read over to me or not, but I stated it—he begged me not to mention it, but I did—I did not mention about his saying he took the linen to his father's house, and cutting it there.

GEORGE WHARTON . I live in Mount-street, Lambeth. I produce a watch which was pawned, on the 14th of August, by Pownall—he merely requested 5s. on it—it is worth about 35s.—I would advance 25s. on it.

SOLOMON AUSTIN . I am shopman to Mr. Philmer. I have a piece of Irish linen which was pawned, on the 14th of August, by the prisoner White, in the name of Smith, for 10s., between three and four o'clock in the afternoon.

JURY. Q. Are you in the habit of taking in pledges of such boys with out more particular inquiry? A. We are always very particular—I asked him his name, the number of his house, and whether he was a lodger—I thought he was sent by his mother to pawn it.
White. It was not him took it in. Witness. It was me, and the ticket is in my handwriting—I did not ask if it was his own—I should say the watch is worth 3l. to me, and the ear-rings 9s.

GEORGE WHARTON
re-examined. The linen is worth 3s. 6d. a yard—I should sell it for that.
MR. PAYNE to WILLIAM SHERLOCK. Q. Was there other property in your place? A. Yes, in the drawer—there was no money, but there was plate, spoons, and a silver ring and necklace.
JURY. Q. Was there any intimacy between your family and Pownall's to lead him to run in and out of your house? A. Certainly not; quite the contrary.
(Catherine Britten, of Duke-street, Lambeth, gave Pownall a good character.)

POWNALL—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor on account of his youth.—
Confined One Year, and then
Transported for Life.

WHITE—
NOT GUILTY .

2013.
HENRY MAY, alias Harris
, was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
James Edward Herepath.

JOHN CLARK . I am a cabinet-maker. I saw a fight take place between the deceased and the prisoner, at Lambeth—they fought about two rounds—the first blow was struck by the prisoner—at the commencement of the second round I saw the prisoner strike the deceased on the left side of his head—the deceased continued to fight after that blow—after it was over I observed him looking for his hat—he was standing by me, and I thought he was coming towards me, but he tumbled and fell, and pitched into the kennel on his knee—he did not speak after that, but merely gave a deep sigh—his head did not come in contact with the ground when he fell then—they had been down together in the scuffle—he had been down twice, but was not knocked down; it was struggling in the fight—they were both down together—no blow was struck on either side after the fight had ceased.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did it appear to you that a push of which the deceased complained before they fought was not intentionally done? A. It did not appear to me that he meant to insult him—it was that the deceased was offended at, and then the prisoner offered to fight—the deceased said "That is what I mean," and prepared to fight—the deceased was sober—I consider the prisoner was in liquor—the deceased remained for about ten minutes after the fight without any thing happening to him.

ARTHUR SKELTON . I am a surgeon, and live in Cornwall-road. On the evening of the 14th of August, I was called to see the deceased—I found him sitting on the curb-stone, with thirty or forty people round him, supported by a policeman and others—I directed him to be taken to the nearest house—I felt his pulse and found it was fluttering—he was not able to speak to me—when I saw him in t. he house he appeared dead—I attempted to bleed him in the left arm—I obtained about half a drachm but could get no more—I did what I could to restore him, but could not—I examined him and could find no 1 external injury at all to account for death—I subsequently examined the body—on removing the scalp, I found no injury internal or external—I took off the cranium, and at the back part of the head there was upwards of an ounce of extravasated blood pressing on the brain, arising from the rupture of a vessel—that effusion was sufficient to account for death—that might have been caused by
excitement, or any external injury, creating an impetus to the blood and forcing an extra rush—it might be occasioned by any additional exertion on his part, or by a blow or fall.

COURT. Q. If you knew nothing of him before, to lead you to suppose he was a subject of apoplexy, and saw him fighting, and afterwards drop down dead, should not you naturally attribute it to the effect of fighting? A. Not unless I saw certain appearances—he was a heavy man and a complete subject for apoplexy—I think it might be produced by excitement on his own part without blows—it might easily be caused by excitement, if the extravasation of blood had taken place in his falling, ten minutes afterwards would be much about the time the effusion would take place after the blow was struck—it would not take twenty minutes for the effect to be developed—it depends on how fast the extravasation took place—sometimes apoplexy comes on slow—excitement might have caused it equally the same as blows—I found the blood on the posterior part of the brain, in such a situation as a blow might be given by a person behind.

Cross-examined. Q. It must be an exceeding hard blow with a fist in such a place to produce that effect? A. Why the man was an exceeding likely subject for apoplexy—vessels so full of blood might easily be ruptured by concussion alone—I think it impossible to distinguish whether his death was caused by excitement, or irritation, or blows—I should be sorry to decide that point.

JOSEPH PUGH . I am a carpenter, and live in Church-terrace, Waterloo road. I saw the prisoner and deceased in the act of closing at the end of the fight—I afterwards saw the deceased looking for his hat—while he was doing so the prisoner struck him unawares at the back of his head—he had left off fighting then, and was inquiring for his hat—the blow caused him to go into the road—he being a much stronger man than the prisoner was able to put the prisoner under him—he staggered from the blow but did not fall—he caught the prisoner by the collar afterwards—I am sure they had done fighting when the blow was given—the deceased expressed that he did not wish to fight, but to keep the prisoner there to give him into custody.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you mean to state that there was no fighting after the blow was struck on the back of the head? A. There was no fighting after—there were only two rounds—there was no other man who threw the deceased. Q. Was there no man that you pointed out as having pushed the deceased into the kennel when he fell? A. There was a man—that was not the prisoner—that man was not fighting with the deceased—the deceased just rolled over—the deceased remained five or ten minutes after it was over before he fell—it was not so much as twenty minutes—the policeman desired him to go away—the policeman asked the landlord to give him into custody for making a disturbance and insisting on staying there—the deceased refused to go as he was waiting for his hat—he said he was waiting for a wonder, and it would be a wonder if he got his hat again—this conversation was about ten minutes after he had received the blow from the prisoner—he stood against the left-hand door post of the beer shop.
MR. SKELTON re-examined. The quantity of extravasated blood I found was too great to allow him to talk ten minutes after the
blow—having heard what I have at this present instant, I think it more probable it was the result of excitement, than from external injury.
NOT GUILTY .

2014.
ANN BROWN and
ELIZABETH WHITE were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July, 1 sock, value 1d.; 1 purse, value 3d.; 2 sovereigns, and 2 half-crowns; the goods and monies of
John Drake Darby.

JOHN DRAKE DARBY . On Wednesday night, the 26th of July, I came out of the Surrey Theatre, and went to the Alfred's Head, and met the two prisoners—I made a proposition to have some supper, and then proposed to go to bed with White—I laid down on the bed—the other prisoner was in the room—this was about ten o'clock—I can swear I had 2l. 5s. and more in my pocket—I put the two sovereigns into my watch fob, and then took them out and put them into my sock, and put it under the pillow—Brown shuffled up and took it from the pillow—I was not aware that she was coming to bed—she had laid down for about two minutes—I did not like my company, I turned round and they both went away, and the sock and money were gone.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you been drinking? A. I had—I had been at the Westminster election, and drank a little there—I was at the Theatre before the performance began—I went in and out, and drank—I sat in the Two Shilling Gallery—I do not know what I paid—I forget now—I went in company with two young women, but neither of these—no gentleman was with me—I cannot tell how much I drank—I drank in small quantities—I was quite sober—I drank only once at the election—it was part of a pot of half-and-half—I had a pint of half-and-half, when I came out of the Theatre, with one of the women—I had one glass of ale at the Alfred's Head—I was in no employment at this time—I drank a little half-and-half at supper—I did not go to sleep—I was wide awake, and saw them go out of the door—I got up, and as soon at I got my clothes on, ran and called the policeman—I was quite sober at the time I lost the money—they were taken the next day, and I was examined on the 28th—I treated the other girls at the Theatre—I gave them no money besides—I had been one day out of place—there is no mark on this purse, but every honest man knows his own purse—there was 5s. in it—I did not see Brown take the money, but it was missing from her side—I saw her scrambling at the pillow—I did not lay hold of her.
JOSEPH JAMES (police-constable M 67.) I received information, and went after the prisoners, and found them—I found nothing on Brown—on White I found two half-crowns, 3 1/2 d., and this purse.
MARY ANN CLARK . I know White. I met her the next morning—she asked me to go and buy a frock with her—she bought one—it cost 4s. 6d.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you taken up on this charge? A. Yes—I have not been tried at the Surrey Sessions—I have been fourteen days at Brixton.
NOT GUILTY .

2015.
TIMOTHY CRAWLEY was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM FLOCKTON . The prisoner was my servant—it was his duty to attend the shop during the absence of the foreman—if he has received 4s. 11d. from Joseph Randall he has never paid it to me—it was his duty
to pay it to the foreman on his return from dinner, having a slate on which he ought to have entered it.
JOSEPH RANDALL . I went to the prosecutor's shop on the 30th of June, and paid the prisoner 4s. 11d. for a pint of oil.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you go a second time to the shop? A. I did on the following Monday—I pointed out the prisoner as the person who had received the money from me—there was a man who came into the shop, and I mistook him for the moment—a man dressed in a sailor's jacket—Mr. Flockton did not tell me it was impossible I could have paid him, as he was not in his employ—the prisoner came in the moment after, and I said it was him—I was asked if I could point out the person, and this other man was behind me—I had but a side view of him.

COURT. Q. Now upon recollection, is it possible you may be mistaken as to the man? A. I am quite positive he charged me for a pound of paint too little, and it was the cause of my knowing him—I paid the money on Friday, and went next on the Monday, and again on Tuesday by request of Mr. Flockton.
JOHN MAHONEY . I am foreman to Mr. Flockton. The prisoner attends when I am away—he did not pay me 4s. 11d. for paint.

Cross-examined. Q. What day was it that Mr. Randall called? A. On a Monday for half a pound of paint—the prisoner was in the yard—I never quarrelled with the prisoner—Randall did not see the prisoner on the second day he came, but on the third—that was Tuesday—he was taken up on Wednesday—the prisoner was accused on Tuesday—he came to work the next day, and was taken on Wednesday night.
NOT GUILTY .

2016.
AMY LAMB was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of June, 1 cap, value 4s.; 1 towel, value 1s.; 1 half-yard of jean, value 4d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 1d., the goods of
James Hillier, her master.

MARY ANN HILLIER . I am the wife of James Hillier. The prisoner was in my employ to nurse me when I was ill—about the 20th of June I lost a cap, towel, half a yard of jean, and a handkerchief—these are the things I lost.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had the prisoner been in the habit of washing for you before you were ill? A. No—I had known her nearly a year and a half—she had done a little needlework for me, which she used to take home to do, while I was ill—she had three shirts and one pair of stays to wash for me—I was confined to my bed, but not at that time—while I was confined to my bed she had none of these to wash, but she had some things to wash and iron—we were very friendly together—I owed her nothing for this nursing—I paid her before she left—she sent a girl to me for the money for washing three shirts—I did not send word by the girl that it was like her impudence to send for the money, and desire her to come herself—I said I wished to see her—I did not send word that if she did not send home the cap I would not pay her at all—she came herself the same day, and I said that I had not found the cap since she was in my house—I did not quarrel with her—she abused me very much—I did not abuse her—this was Tuesday—I paid her 1s.—she was satisfied—she did not demand another—I sent a person to know if she had any further demand on me, and she had not—I took a policeman a week afterwards—that was the first time of my going out since my illness—I accompanied the officer, and upon unlocking her drawer, the first thing the officer found was this towel—I charge it to be worth 1s.—I said

I lent her the towel to defend her, as the called me to the back garden when the officer found the things, and begged of me not to own them—the cap was washed, starched, and rough dried, preparatory to being ironed, when it was found—I value this at 4s.—she did not say she had it to wash, and would not return it till I paid another shilling—she never had it to wash for me—this is the piece of jean, it is worth 4d., and this handkerchief 1d.—all these things were put by rough dried—I had two collars belonging to the prisoner that she gave me—she asked for them again, and I returned them—she asked me for a pair of gloves.
NOT GUILTY .

2017.
SAMUEL SMITH was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July 1 sugar-bason, value 2l. 10s.; and 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Evans: and 1 watch; value 15s.; 1 chain, value 6d.; and 1 seal, value 2s.; the goods of
Adam Alexander Thompson: and
ROBERT BRIGHT
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.—3rd COUNT, for receiving them of an evil disposed person.

THOMAS EVANS . I live in Great Guildford-street, Southwark. On the 12th of July I went to my house and found a watch was gone from the mantel-piece—it belonged to Adam Alexander Thompson—I saw it safe about twenty minutes previous—I found I had lost a silver sugar-bason and tongs—they were my own—this is the bason and tongs and watch.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. How long had you seen these other things before? A. I cannot say, because my partner took the bason out of the cupboard—I had seen them within a day or two—there is no mark whatever on them, but the balls have been marked with a pin—mine had two pin holes—the tongs are not found.

JAMES SAUNDERS . I was standing opposite the prosecutor's about four o'clock, on the 12th of July, and I saw the prisoner Smith come out with a parcel in his hand in a red handkerchief—he had no shoes on—he met another lad, and the lad he met gave the prisoner his shoes, and took the parcel in the red handkerchief from him.
Smith. If I waited to put on the shoes, why did he not come and catch hold of me?

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I went on the night of the same day, and took Smith near St. George's Church, at twelve o'clock at night—I told him I wanted him for a felony—he made no reply—I took him to the station-house—he was locked up, and I and my brother officer went to Bright's house, and knocked at the door—he and his wife were in bed—I told him I wanted him on suspicion of receiving a watch, sugar-bason, and chain and seals—he said "You must be mistaken, as I know nothing about it"—we searched and found the sugar-bason in a hat-box.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there any one else in the house? A. I believe there were two children—I found the hat-box in the front shop—there were several hat boxes piled up, but no hats in them—this was an open box without a lid—there were others piled on the top of it, and an old flannel petticoat put over the sugar-bason.
CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 31.) I went to Bright's and found 113 duplicates, and among them was one for this watch, which led me to a pawnbroker, where I found the watch.
Cross-examined. Q. You returned some? A. Yes, because I found they belonged to the prisoner.
THOMAS ROWLEY . I was in the employ of Mr. Harris of the Minories,
a pawnbroker—I have the watch which was pawned by Bright, on the evening of the 12th of July.
(Property produced and sworn to.) Smith. I know nothing at all about them.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 15—
Confined Two Years; Two Months Solitary.

BRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 22—
Transported for Seven Years.

2018.
GEORGE COLSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of July, 1 boat, value 3l. 15s.; 2 sculls, value 5s., the goods of
Benjamin Joseph Spedding, and another: 66l. bs. weight of rope, value 4s., the goods of
Richard Beard: 10l. bs. weight of rope, value 6d., the goods of
Edward Wood: 28l. bs. weight of rope, value 2s., the goods of James Heighington, and another; and 22l. bs. weight of rope, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
James Wilson.
JAMES WARD . I am partner the of Benjamin Joseph Spedding—I do not know the prisoner—we have lost a boat and two sculls—these are our sculls.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYME. Q. When had you seen them? A.
The evening before—I do not know that it is the custom to borrow boats, and bring them back.

JOSHUA JUDGE . I am a Thames police surveyor. On Thursday, the 13th of July, between five and six o'clock in the morning, I went and found a boat with "Spedding and Co." on it, with a quantity of rope on board it, which had been cut—this was on the side of Chamberlain's Wharf, in the parish of St. Olave's, Southwark—Mr. Spedding lives in Pedlar's-acre, near Westminister-bridge—this is the rope that was found in it—it is what is called head-fasts—I left Bartlett in the boat to watch, and he brought the boat and the prisoner to me.
GEORGE ROGERS . This rope is my master's—I had seen it safe on Wednesday evening the 12th, between eight and nine o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Where had you seen it? A. In the Sally Barge cabin, which was moored off Purfleet Wharf, Earl-street—it is the property of Richard Beard—I know it by the splicing on it.

ALEXANDER TOUGH . I am a lighterman in the employ of Mr. Edward Wood. I have seen part of a head-fast, which is my master's property—I saw it safe on Wednesday night, between nine and ten o'clock, at Northumberland Wharf, Strand, fastened round a pile, to a barge—I can swear it belongs to Mr. Edward Wood.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it? A. By my employer's name written on a piece of linen—Northumberland Wharf is hardly a quarter of a mile from Mr. Spedding's—it is across the water—one is at Westminister-bridge, the other at Hungerford—one in Surrey, and the other in Middlesex.

JOSEPH ALCE . I live at No. 25, Royal-street, and am a lighterman to John Heighington, of Hatfield-street. Here is one head-fast and two pieces—I saw them safe on Wednesday evening, at seven or eight o'clock—they are Mr. Heighington's and his brother's.
Cross-examined. Q. Where does Mr. Heighington live? A. At No. 2, Hatfield-street, Christ Church, Surrey, about a mile from Spedding's—I know it by a piece of blue worsted in it.

JOHN BARTHOLOMEW BARTLETT . I am a Thames-police officer. I was placed to watch at Chamberlain's Wharf, St. Olave's—I watched there from five or six o'clock till seven—I saw the prisoner come down the

wharf and get into the skiff, and undo it and shove it away—I jumped into the skiff, and asked him what he was going to do with the rope—he said he was going to sell it, that it was his perquisite—I then delivered him and the boat and rope to Mr. Judge.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2019.
THOMAS BERRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of August, 5 pairs of shoes, value 1l. 5s., the goods of
Edward Wallis.
EDWARD WALLIS . I am a boot and shoemaker, and live in Lambeth-marsh. I lost some shoes on the 15th of August—they were safe that day at twelve o'clock, and missed at two—these are them.

JAMES WILTSHIRE . I am an apprentice to the prosecutor. Between two and three o'clock that day I saw the prisoner take these shoes from the door—I ran after him—he threw them down and ran away—I am sure the prisoner was the man—there was another with him, he was secured.
Prisoner. I never had them in my possession at all—when I was taken I was walking along.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months; Six Weeks Solitary.

2020.
WILLIAM BOUTE was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of August, 1 hone, value 6s., and 1 razor, value 2s.; the goods of
Charles Atkinson.
CHARLES ATKINSON . I keep a shop at Lambeth. The prisoner came in on the 8th of August—I left my shop while he was there—I missed a razor and hone the next day.
Prisoner. Q. By what mark do you know this razor and hone, are there not fifty or a hundred by the same maker? A. I know them by the look of them and the maker's name—I have used them a long while.

JOHN THORNTON . The prisoner came to me, and told me he had bought a bargain, and showed me this hone and razor—this was Tuesday evening, the 8th of August—I kept them till the next day, and gave them to the officer—he did not offer to sell them—I believe he left them by mistake.

Prisoner. I was passing Whitechapel, and had a glass of half-and-half, and a man offered me these for sale—I gave him 1s. 9d. for the hone, and 6d. for the razor, which was 2s. 3d., all I had, and he took that for them—the prosecutor has lodgers in the house, and there is free admission for any one to take these things.
CHARLES ATKINSON . We have lodgers, and they can have access to the shop—this is one that I had used—it was not for sale.
(Robert Downing, a hair-dresser, of No. 81, Snow-hill, gave the prisoner a good character, and offered to take him into his employ.)

GUILTY .—Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—
Confined One Month; One Week Solitary.

2021.
HENRY AMBRIDGE was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of July, 16 yards of silk, value 2l. 18s.; 1 shawl, value 6s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 15s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 5s.; 2 yards l- 8th of woollen cloth, value 1l. 11s.; and 2 1/4 yards of kerseymere, value 15s. 9d.; the goods of
John Cuthbertson, his master.

JOHN CUTHBERTSON . I am a linen-draper, and live in the Borough road, Southwark. The prisoner was in my service—I missed this silk, and shawl, and other things—I believe these to be mine—(looking at them)—the prisoner had an opportunity of taking them.

SARAH KNIGHT . I live at No. 21, John-street, Waterloo-road, and before that in William-street. The prisoner used to come and see me there—these sixteen yards of silk, and shawl, and stockings, were found at my lodgings—the prisoner made me a present of them.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2022.
JOHN CLIFF was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of August, 2 pairs of boots, value 10s., the goods of
William Green, his master.

WILLIAM GREEN . I am a shoemaker. The prisoner was my journeyman. On the 15th of August I gave him two pairs of boots to take to a customer—he never came back to me afterwards till the next night; and on Thursday morning I had him taken up—I spoke to him about it—he said he had sold them, and got the money.
Prisoner. Q. What is the price that you set on them? A. 10s.—I told him, if he had pledged the boots, I could get them again, and I would forgive him; but he had robbed me twice before.
Prisoner. On the day I arrived at home he told my wife, before a neighbour, that if I would come home, and return to my work, he would take it out of my work.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined One Month.

2023.
MARGARET DANIEL was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July, 1 watch, value 30s.; 1 split ring, value 2d.; 1 watch-key, value 2d.; and 1 watch-ribbon, value 1d.; the goods of
John Williams: and
DANIEL MORRIS
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to be stolen; against the Statute, &c.—2nd COUNT, for receiving them of an evil disposed person.
(The prosecutor did not appear.)
NOT GUILTY .

2024.
FREDERICK BROOKS and
GEORGE BAKER were indicted for
a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1837.
